data.title: Sancta Nomina
data.meta_description: 10 posts published by sanctanomina during April 2016
data.text:
Iâ€™m popping back on to post todayâ€™s scheduled consultation, and thank you for your kind words and prayers for my mother-in-law and our family!

Kate and her husband are expecting their second baby! Their older son is:

William Finn, who goes by Finn

Love love love. I adore Finn, and itâ€™s SO cool that itâ€™s a middle for William.

Kate writes,

â€œFinnâ€™s first name was a no-brainer because itâ€™s a meaningful family name on both sides â€¦ [however we] could not agree on a nickname for William (I like Bill or maybe Will, he liked Liam but I didnâ€™t) so we decided to just call him by his middle name. I donâ€™t even remember how we came across Finn, but [my hubsâ€™] family identifies strongly with their Irish heritage and I thought it was cute, so it was a winner.

This baby is probably a girl (per an early ultrasound), but weâ€™re looking for both a girl and boy name in case he/she changes her mind at the anatomy scan. ğŸ˜‰

My husband and I have very different naming styles â€” and personalities altogether â€” which made it a miracle we decided on Finnâ€™s name and is making it very difficult this time around â€¦ my style is a little more â€œhipsterâ€, his is a lot more plain-Jane (his words, not mine!) We are both leaning towards a French name for a girl this time around (my family is French and Polish.)â€œ

For girls,

â€œour top contender for Finn was Geneva Eloise. Geneva is a family name on Jeffâ€™s side, a great-grandmother he was very close to. I still like it, but Iâ€™m not sure I love it. We were/are considering the nickname Vivi or Gemma.

For middle names with Geneva, I like Stellamaris and Azelie, but am open to more ideas. Iâ€™m not sure they sound quite right. I/we are also open to new first name ideas though Jeff says heâ€™s very attached to Geneva. Other family names are Margaret (my side), Aileen (my side), Helen (his side.)â€œ

And for boys,

â€œwe have literally zero ideas. I love Francis and Walter, my husband does not like either. We have no new ideas. Anything would help.â€

Okay! Not to fear! I can always come up with ideas! ğŸ˜€ I love Geneva Eloise with the nicknames Vivi or Gemma, so sweet! I also love Stellamaris and Azelie as middle names. I have nothing more to say, theyâ€™re just great ideas.

For those who donâ€™t know, I almost always start my consultations by looking up all the names the parents have used and liked in the Baby Name Wizard book as it lists, for each entry, boy and girl names that match the entry in terms of style/feel/popularity. Itâ€™s uncannily accurate! Between that research and other, and my own namey head, these are my suggestions for boy and girl names (I tried to be heavier on the boy names but ended up with seven suggestions for each gender!):

Girl

(1) Genevieve or Vivienne

Geneva made me think of Genevieve right away, so Kate and her hubs probably wonâ€™t like it, since Genevaâ€™s a family name and Genevieve loses that, but I had to suggest it. Or maybe it could be seen as a nod to Geneva while giving the baby her own name? St. Genevieve is the patron saint of Paris, which is great! And Vivienne also has the strong V sound and the French spelling, and both Genevieve and Vivienne can take the nicknames Vivi or Evie. So cute!

(2) Juliette

Julietâ€™s one of my very favorites, and Julietteâ€™s a beautiful French variant. Lovely!

(3) Sylvie

When I saw Sylvia pop up in my research, I immediately thought of Sylvie and thought it was a great suggestion for this family! Itâ€™s got the V of Geneva, and itâ€™s kind of like Sophie but not nearly as popular. This reader named her baby Sylvie Regina, which I just about died over! It sounds so like the Marian hymn â€œSalve Regina,â€ so cool!

(4) Beatrice

This also showed up in my research, and it reminded me of the family I did a consultation for recently whose mom is from France, and all the girls have French names. Beatrice made me think of it because itâ€™s the momâ€™s name, and Bea is one of my favorite nicknames for a little girl.

(5) Clementine

Clementine is actually a style match for Eloise, I love it! Not least because itâ€™s a â€œmercyâ€ name â€” perfect for a baby born during the Year of Mercy!

(6) Helene

I wondered what theyâ€™d think of Helene? Kate said that Helen and Aileen are family names, and Aileen is sometimes considered an Irish variant of Helen, and Helene is the French variant. That same French family I mentioned above has Helene as one of the girlsâ€™ middle names, itâ€™s a beautiful name, and St. Helena is great. Nell is a great nickname for Helene, a la little Helen Borobia, who sometimes gets called Nellie Peg (for Helen Margaret! I die!)!!

(7) Magdalen(e) or Madeleine

Magdalen(e) just seemed like a name Kate and her hubs would like, and I have no real reason except my gut feeling! The French variant is Madeleine of course, but I donâ€™t know, I was just feeling Magdalen(e) for this family. I love that you can get Maggie as a nickname, which is always so darling. But Iâ€™d be 100% happy with Madeleine too, and if they liked the combo Madeleine Sophie,after St. Madeleine Sophie Barat, Iâ€™d be even happier!

Boy

(1) Robert nicked Rory

I was really excited to get into the boy names! William Finn is just the greatest combo, so I feel like it has some big shoes to fill. The first one I thought of right off the bat was Robert as a first name with the nickname Rory. Robert is a style match for William and Rory is a style match for Finn and I just totally love this option.

(2) George nicked Geo or Geordie

Can you all see that Iâ€™m going for a solid, traditional first name with a more offbeat nickname? I love that! I love the nickname Geo for George, so cool! Another possibility, which is really fun, is Geordie (pronounced Jordy), which I believe is a Scottish diminutive of George. (Fun fact: I have ALWAYS been in love with the nickname Jordy and tried to get my husband on board. I was never successful.)

(3) Theodore or Leo

Theodore matched up with Geneva and Francis style-wise, so of course I had to suggest it, and Iâ€™d actually already scribbled Leo in my notes for this baby before Iâ€™d even started doing research, because my brother and SIL â€” whose taste seems to me to be pretty similar to Kate and her husbandâ€™s â€” named their son Leo. Theo and Leo share sounds, so Iâ€™d say it might be a matter of do they prefer short (Leo) or long with a shorter nickname (Theodore/Theo)?

(4) Jude (Julian?)

Jude and Finn are amazing brother names in my opinion! Jude also has that Catholic cachet thatâ€™s so great. Iâ€™ve seen Jude used as a nickname for Julian, and the Beatlesâ€™ song Hey Jude was written for Julian Lennon, so there is precedent for doing so, and I thought Kate and her hubs might like that option.

(5) Owen

This is another one informed both by the style of Finn, and by my brother and SIL, who named their Leoâ€™s little brother Owen! St. Nicholas Owen is an awesome patron for a little Owen.

(6) Conrad or Connor

Conrad probably seems a little bit out of left field, but itâ€™s a style match for both Geneva and Eloise, so I thought it deserved a mention. I love the name Conrad, and my hubs and I actually considered it for our youngest! I could also see Conner used as a nickname, which is pretty cool and pretty similar to Finn. Or maybe Connor as a first name? I love it!

(7) Arthur nicked Archie or Abe

Arthur is totally because they like Francis and Walter! And Archie and Abe are nicknames Iâ€™ve recently seen used by parents of Arthurs, who were total hipsters. I love Archie, I think thatâ€™s brilliant for Arthur; the Arthur whoâ€™s Abe has a B middle name, so it makes sense, so perfect.

And those are my ideas! What do you all think? What name(s) would you suggest for the little brother or sister of William Finn?

Shannon, from the blog We, A Great Parade, and her husband are expecting their third baby and third son! This new baby boy will join big brothers:

Alyosha Daniel

Moses Emmanuel

Amazing, right? Handsome, unusual, and full of faith significance, love them. ğŸ‘Œ

Shannon writes,

â€œOur first son was adopted at 11 months old from Uganda â€¦ We chose Alyosha because of the main character in The Brothers Karamazov and also loved that it means â€œdefender of mankindâ€. We chose Daniel because we wanted a solid, simple Biblical name to balance out the unusual first name. At the time we were Protestant, but now that weâ€™re Catholic I like that his name is somewhat related to St. Aloysius.

Our second son (first biological baby) is named Moses Emmanuel â€¦ We chose Moses obviously because of the Biblical character but also because we just really liked the name. And Iâ€™ve kind of loosely made St. Moses the Black his patron ğŸ™‚ We chose Emmanuel because he was born during Advent.

Soâ€¦ we love names that are less commonly used but that also bear significance because of a person (even fictitious) that they represent. While we do love saints names, we couldnâ€™t just pick a random one simply because we liked it. We would want the person to reflect a trait that is particularly dear to us, OR for the name meaning itself to do so.

We are devoted to the teachings of the Catholic Worker, so people like Dorothy Day or Peter Maurin are ones we have kept in mind in addition to saints. Weâ€™re trying to steer away from Biblical figures at this point since we already have a Daniel and a Moses. Additionally, since our oldest son is adopted and a different race than the rest of us, we ideally would like to avoid using the letter M in the first name â€¦ since that would subtly group together the biological boys and leave him out. That may be something we change our minds on, but is where weâ€™re at right now.â€

I really enjoyed thinking of Shannonâ€™s three boys and her and her husbandâ€™s lovely desire that Alyosha not feel left out name-wise. I also enjoyed having the opportunity to learn more about Servant of God Dorothy Day, one of the four Americans Pope Francis mentioned in his Address to Congress in September, and Peter Maurin, neither of whom Iâ€™d known much about before Shannonâ€™s email. All in all, this was a really great dilemma to work on!

Names that are currently on their list include:

Oliver (â€œI think itâ€™s super cute, we love that it symbolizes peace, and my family is Irish so naming after St. Oliver would be a kind of homage to thatâ€¦ BUT we donâ€™t know anything about him really.â€)

Theodore (â€œAgain a really cute name, great meaning (gracious gift), but again donâ€™t know much about the saintâ€œ)

Brien (â€œonly as a middle nameâ€¦ my maiden name is Oâ€™Brien and Iâ€™d like to pass it onâ€œ)

Maurin (â€œafter Peter Maurinâ€¦ we both love this one but we run into the problem with the M. Peter is just too common for our tastes. Any creative ideas for a nickname maybe?? Weâ€™ve also thought about Day for Dorothy Day, maybe too short and awkward though. Or Aristide which is Maurinâ€™s first name, but my hubs says Aris is too weirdâ€œ)

Basil (â€œmy husband likes saint Basil, and favors this name, but Iâ€™m afraid it would come across as hipster to the majority of the world, along the lines of Sage, Juniper, Willow, etcâ€œ)

Tevye (â€œthe Yiddish version of Tobias, another person we donâ€™t actually know much about. My husband likes this one too but Iâ€™m not sold because it doesnâ€™t mean anything special to meâ€œ)

Okay, a quick comment on some of the ideas on their current list before jumping into my ideas:

I love Oliver, and I totally agree that itâ€™s super cute. St. Oliver Plunket is a great saint for a boy, especially an Irish boy, and one of the things Iâ€™ve learned about him recently is that he wrote about Divine Mercy â€” what a meaningful tidbit for a baby born during this Jubilee Year of Mercy!

Theodoreâ€™s a great name too, but it feels a little tame for this familyâ€™s taste. I could see them liking the variant Fyodor more, but is that too much Karamazov Bros.? At the same time it could be really great â€” Moses and the new baby have the biological connection; Alyosha and the new baby would have a Russian/Karamazov name connection.

I was interested by Maurin. If it werenâ€™t for the M, it seems like it would be a perfect name for Shannon and her hubs â€” offbeat because of it being a last name, and the name of a man they admire. Shannon asked about a nickname â€” Maury and Manny were the first two that came to mind. But that pesky M â€” I agree that maybe an M name wouldnâ€™t ideal for this baby (unless they change their minds on that, and then of course Iâ€™d support their decision 100%!) â€¦ then I thought of Aury, which is a little bit of a stretch but not THAT much of a stretch. I looked it up to be sure it wasnâ€™t considered a girlâ€™s name (since I know how fussed any of my boys would be if they had what they consider a â€œgirlâ€™s name,â€ especially if the other brothers had explicitly masculine names), and though I couldnâ€™t find much about Aury, what I did find (babynamewizard.com had an entry for â€œAury Estela,â€ a girlâ€™s name, and behindthename had a user-submitted entry saying Aury is a boyâ€™s name â€¦ babycenter.com had Aury listed as a boyâ€™s name as well, but no other info) leads me to think thereâ€™s enough evidence that itâ€™s not overwhelmingly considered to be feminine and therefore could easily be used for a boy. I kind of liked the idea of a given name Maurin â€” starting with an M like brother Moses â€” being called Aury on an everyday basis, which starts with an A like brother Alyosha. I thought that could be a really nice subtle connection between all the brothers, and not so obvious that theyâ€™d feel locked into anything if they were to have more children.

I like the idea of Day, and I saw it used recently as a middle name for a girl (for Dorothy Day) â€” so cool! As a first name itâ€™s certainly short, but so is Todd, for example, so I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s problematic. I guess Iâ€™m having a hard time thinking of it on a boy, since the two people I associate with the name are Dorothy Day and that little girl I know with the middle name Day â€¦ but of course last names are a great source of first names for boys â€¦ Iâ€™d love to know what the rest of you think of Day as a first name for a boy! I would love it as a middle name.

I have similar issues with Basil as Shannon does â€” I love it, and I think itâ€™s a great, underused saintâ€™s name, but I hate that most Americans would only think of the herb. I looked up its alternate versions in other languages, and wondered what Shannon and her Mr. would think of one of the Eastern European variants like Vasil or Vasyl? I assume theyâ€™re pronounced to rhyme with Basil, and the V and B are so similar that itâ€™s almost exactly the same name sound-wise, but it loses the herb/hippie feel.

I was surprised by Tevye because itâ€™s a biblical name and Shannon had said they wanted to stay away from them. So then I assumed she meant they wanted to stay away from biblical names that *sound* biblical to Catholic Americans, which I think is easier to work with than â€œno biblical names,â€ and I employed this in one of my ideas below.

Okay! So onto those ideas! You all know that I almost always start a consultation by looking up the names that the parents have used and the ones that they like in the Baby Name Wizard as it lists, for each entry, boy and girl names that are similar in terms of style/feel/popularity. Taste like this familyâ€™s, which is more creative and offbeat, tends not to be served as well by the BNW, but I did get some ideas from it, as well as from my own mental archives:

(1) Julius or Julian/Julien

The BNW actually came through in a big way with this first suggestionâ€”Julius was listed as similar to both Moses and Theodore! And Julian is a style match for Oliver! So of course I had to suggest these names. But thenâ€”I was researching Peter Maurin a little bit and discovered that he was born in the village of Oultet within the community of Saint-Julien-du-Tournel! What! I got goosebumps when I read that!

(2) Ciar(an)

I was thinking of various ways of naming Shannonâ€™s third boy that would make sure Alyosha didnâ€™t feel left out in any way, and one of the ideas I had was to make sure this baby boy had a name completely different from either of his brothersâ€™ names in terms of first letter and linguistic origin/variant, just like Moses and Alyosha are totally different. Itâ€™s one of the reasons I like Oliverâ€”itâ€™s Irish/Celtic/British, which is totally different from Alyosha and Moses. But then I was also thinking thatâ€”and I hope this doesnâ€™t seem insensitive at allâ€”both of her other boys share the color blackâ€”Alyosha in his skin and Moses in his patron saint of Moses the Black. So I kind of loved that Ciar means black in Irishâ€”it ties into the really subtle shared black characteristic of her boys while still being its own name totally different from the other two. Ciar is a name on its own (said like KEER), and the more familiar Ciaran (KEER-in, more commonly spelled Kieran) is technically a diminutive of Ciar.

(Along with this same line of thinking, itâ€™s pretty cool to know that Maurin is related to Mauritz/Maurus/Maurinus, all of which mean â€œdark skinned,â€ so if Shannon and her hubs do decide to go that route, that have that connection between all the brothers.)

(3) Jasper

Jasper was listed as a style match for Oliver, and itâ€™s also a gemstone that can be black, tying into the idea I presented with Ciar(an) above. Black jasper is not very common, but it was cool to read that the â€œname blackstones refer to any number of stones, including jasper, that are dyed black and polished for jewellery.â€ Jasper is the name traditionally given to one of the Three Wise Men (you might also see its variants Casper and Gaspar given for that same Wise Manâ€”theyâ€™re all the same name).

(4) Form of Peter

This is the idea I mentioned that Tevye, being biblical but not obviously so to most English speakers I think, inspired, as well as Peter Maurin of course. Shannon said theyâ€™d considered Maurinâ€™s first name Aristide and its variant and possible nickname Aris, but I wonder if theyâ€™d considered any of the Peter variants? They arenâ€™t obviously biblical to English speakers, but would still honor Maurin pretty explicitly. Pierre would be a great one, since Maurin was French; Piers is an English variant; Peadar is Irish and is said more like PAD-der (patter).

(5) Clement

Clement was inspired both by the Jubilee Year of Mercy, as it means â€œmerciful,â€ and Iâ€™m a big fan of the idea of naming babies born this year with some element of mercy in their names!, and also by the fact that Shannonâ€™s due in May, which is the month devoted to Our Lady, and Clement can be considered Marian (as sheâ€™s described as clement [=merciful] in the hymn/prayer Salve Regina, for example).

But after Iâ€™d already decided to suggest Clement to them for those reasons, I came upon this quote of Dorothy Dayâ€™s in regard to the Catholic Worker: â€œOur rule is the works of mercy,â€ and one of its tenets is â€œdaily practice of the Works of Mercy.â€ What a meaningful name Clement would be for this family on so many levels!

(6) Cyprian

Along the same lines as the â€œblackâ€ idea above, I thought maybe the name of an African saint would be cool, and I immediately thought of Bl. Cyprian Michael Iwene Tansi. Cyprianâ€™s a cool name and unusual, I really like it for this family.

(7) Roman or Tiber

I liked Roman as an idea for this baby initially because it has a long O like Aloysha and Moses, another subtle connection between the brothers, and the reason I liked that particular name-with-a-long-o is because I always think of Roman as a Catholicky Catholic name, as it calls to mind (for me) the Vatican, the Pope, Roman Catholic, etc.

Thinking along those lines also made me think of Tiber, which is the name of a river in Rome, and the phrase â€œcrossing the Tiberâ€ refers to someone converting to Catholicism. Itâ€™s a really cool name with a really cool meaning for convert parents. (Check out an adorable Tiber here. ğŸ™‚ ).

And those are my ideas! What do you all think? What would you suggest for Alyosha and Mosesâ€™ little brother?

Okay everyone, buckle up â€” this is a daddy of a consultation! In more ways than one! Yes, itâ€™s really long (twenty-three ideas for this couple! What!) (Youâ€™ll see why!), and also, itâ€™s a papa that commissioned me to do this consultation!

Cameron is one of my most loyal and encouraging readers, and Iâ€™m delighted today to post this consultation for he and his wife Chelsey, who are expecting their first baby â€” a boy!

C&C have fully agreed on Jude Alden as an amazing combo that they both love, that has great meaning for them as well â€” a great, saintly first name and a nod to Chelseyâ€™s dad in the middle.

But what would a consultation be without a dilemma? For this couple, itâ€™s that Cameronâ€™s full name is John Cameron, and his dadâ€™s first name is John as well. Cameron loves the idea of giving his firstborn son the first name John, like he and his dad, and have him go by his middle name. BUT he and Chelsey love Jude Alden. And they canâ€™t figure out a John ___ name they like as much or better.

Cameron writes,

â€œSince my dad and I are both first borns and both have â€œJohnâ€ as our first name, I always thought itâ€™d be really cool to turn that into a tradition should God bless me with a boy first â€¦ Jude Alden just hit us in the face one day when we were out and about and we just stopped and knew right away that we loved that name. It is a power hitter name regards to our faith; being one of the apostles, and honors Chelseyâ€™s father for his middle name! ğŸ™‚

[I feel like] Jude Alden is the perfect nameâ€¦ for a younger brother. Chelsey would gladly name it for the first born â€¦ However, after having that discussion with you a while back regarding Jude in the spotlight, I have heavily considered giving up my â€œmade up tradition of John + somethingâ€ to replace it with Jude Alden as a first born, thinking that maybe weâ€™ll never get the chance to use the only name weâ€™ve both come up with and loved.

Obviously Jude Alden is the forerunner. It could very possibly happen that when we see our boy, we just know itâ€™s a Jude and thatâ€™s that. We are coming to you to help us with our â€œJohn Dilemmaâ€.

John is the beloved apostle and I (Cameron) have a dear devotion to him and his connection with Our Lady. I love John for being a very strong solid name, and the thought of tying in another name to that is so exciting. But Jude Alden is stellarâ€¦ who knows.â€

(Cameron calls it a â€œmade up traditionâ€ because he wasnâ€™t actually named John [something] *because* his dad was, it just worked out that way.)

Except for Jude Alden, Cameron and Chelsey have pretty different taste in names. For Cameron,

â€œI personally am not a big fan of super â€œsecularâ€ sounding names like â€œHunter, Derek, Brad, Jordan, etcâ€¦â€ or names along those lines for the MAIN NAME that we would call our child. We have tossed around ideas including a secular name as a middle name (or first, doesnâ€™t matter what order, really) for example, but not the name we could call him. That includes several, obviously, so I wouldnâ€™t write all those out. â€¦ I love good solid Catholic names. You know that. Raphael, Gabriel, Paul, John, Jude, Titus, Daniel. Chelsey and I have been thinking about not being TOO obsessive (mainly me) about having a super well known Catholic name, because we love the thoughts of our children being new saints, thus creating a new name for other families using in reverence and honorâ€¦.if that makes sense.â€

(I totally cracked up at this: â€œChelsey and I have been thinking about not being TOO obsessive (mainly me) about having a super well known Catholic nameâ€!! ğŸ˜€ )

Chelsey, on the other hand,

â€œlikes uniquenessâ€¦ Chelsey likes names that are a little bit more â€œrareâ€ but still have a good sound to it, if that makes sense â€¦ [she doesnâ€™t] like names that are very common, and [sheâ€™s] also not a fan of names that can appear boring, e.g. Paul, Bob, Tom, Sam, etc.. Some names [she does] like are killed by the shortened versions e.g. Elijah- Eli.â€

Names Cameron likes but Chelsey doesnâ€™t:

Paul (â€œIâ€™d totally go for John Paul for obvious reasons, JPII!!!â€œ)

Ezekiel

Isaac

Raphael

Samuel

August (â€œboooooâ€ [John August is Cameronâ€™s favorite combo])

Elijah

Dominic

Name Chelsey likes but Cameron doesnâ€™t:

Ezra

Name they both kind of like:

Ignatius (but Cameron worries that itâ€™s â€œSUCH a heavy hitter, that it almost seems to be too muchâ€œ)

Names that are no-goâ€™s:

Garett

Graham

And finally, for reference, some girlsâ€™ names theyâ€™ve discussed and like:

Lillian

Grace/Gracie

Willow

Haven

Noelle

Alrighty, first off, the idea of John+[something] is just one of those things that canâ€™t be ignored. You know? On the one hand, I want to say that Jude Alden, being the name Cameron and Chelsey both agree on and love, is the perfect option for their little boy. On the other hand, naming traditions can be so meaningful, and given that John+something is Cameronâ€™s name and his dadâ€™s name, as firstborns, I donâ€™t think itâ€™s the kind of thing that they can shelve for now and maybe consider if they ever have a second boy. I think this baby boy here is their one shot at John+something. So thatâ€™s kind of a lot of pressure! It might seem like theyâ€™re down to â€œfamily traditionâ€ (which happens to nicely coincide with Cameronâ€™s particular devotion to St. John the Evangelist and Our Lady, beautiful) vs. â€œfavorite name, and the one we can happily agree on.â€

I posted a while ago on whether parents should reserve names for later use at the expense of using them now or vice versa (in that example it was â€œFelix now at the expense of Felicity later?â€ but it works perfectly for John+[something] vs. Jude Alden) and two things that came up in the comments seemed really helpful: (1) name this baby as if he/she were your last baby, and (2) in light of that, which name would you be sadder not to ever get to use? If this little boy is the only little boy that C&C are ever blessed with, would they be sadder to not use John as a first name in the tradition of Cameron and his dad, or the handsome and agreed-upon combo Jude Alden? (Cameron actually commented on that post â€” this is a really hard dilemma for them, which has been hanging over them for a while!) (Also, if you want to get a glimpse of these sweetest expectant parents, click on his username!)

So my main goals (and my hopes for you all in the comments!) is either to come up with a John+ name that will make them both really happy and not feel like theyâ€™re settling, or help them realize Jude Alden is *the* answer, and either way not set them up for name regret later. Cameron started emailing me about this dilemma several months ago, and weâ€™ve had quite a long conversation about it â€” Iâ€™ve suggested several (where â€œseveralâ€=â€23â€) ideas to them, and since none of them have hit quite the right note, I hope you all can come up with something thatâ€™s just right (or maybe Jude Alden is meant to be this little boyâ€™s name?). My ideas are:

(1) John Alden, called Jude

This is probably my top option. It has all three of the elements they both want: John, Alden, and Jude. I know itâ€™s an offbeat idea â€” you all know I totally specialize in offbeat nickname ideas! So I get it if itâ€™s just too crazy for C&C. Itâ€™s the kind of choice that theyâ€™d really have to be 100% with and just own it â€” telling people firmly and consistently that yes, his given name is John Alden, and yes, heâ€™s called Jude exclusively.

(2) John Jude Alden, called Jude

The two-middle name option isnâ€™t for everyone, but itâ€™s a tactic often employed when there are a bunch of names that parents canâ€™t choose between.

(3) John Thaddeus, called Jude

This is probably the one thatâ€™s closest to my own personal taste. Thaddeus is after St. Jude Thaddeus, and I think his full name is familiar enough to people that if you say his name is John Thaddeus but youâ€™re calling him Jude, people will probably raise eyebrows because itâ€™s an unorthodox way of getting to Jude, but I donâ€™t think theyâ€™d be like, â€œWhere the heck do you get Jude from John Thaddeus??â€ Another nice thing is that with the â€œJâ€ of John and the â€œudeâ€ thatâ€™s contained within Thaddeus, Jude is almost like a mashup nickname of the first+middle names. Finally, Thaddeus is a style match for Ignatius and Raphael â€” itâ€™s got loads of Catholic cachet; itâ€™s also super biblical like Chelseyâ€™s Ezra and several of the names Cameron likes. If they were to go with John Thaddeus nicked Jude, theyâ€™d have two of their three important elements â€” John and Jude. Itâ€™ll be important to consider whether or not Chelseyâ€™s dad will be upset with not being included in their first sonâ€™s name.

(4) John Ignatius

I think itâ€™s really telling that C&C are both considering Ignatius â€” besides Jude Alden, itâ€™s the only name they listed that theyâ€™re both okay with! John Ignatius is an amazing combo. I know that Cameron said he doesnâ€™t like the â€œmain nameâ€ their son will be called (sometimes called a â€œcall nameâ€ in the naming world) to sound secular, which I totally get. But I suspect that Chelsey might not mind that so much, and perhaps a good compromise between their tastes would be a heavy hitting super duper Catholicky Catholic given name, like John Ignatius, with a friendlier, more accessible nickname/call name, which I think usually sound secular. I donâ€™t think Gus translates as Catholic, for example, even though St. Augustine is such a big deal, and Gus is a natural nickname for it. Does that make sense?
